knowledge_zone.heading: Imagery: Sensory grounding and vivid description

sections.content: Imagery is used throughout the text to sensory grounding and vivid description.

examples.quote: dark green uniforms, with heavy belts
examples.scene: Description of Memory Police officers at the door
examples.effect: Provides vivid sensory details that establish the oppressive atmosphere and mechanical uniformity of the authoritarian force

examples.quote: The flames, like some enormous living creature, shot up to the sky
examples.scene: Arrival at the central park book burning
examples.effect: Creates vivid sensory documentation of totalitarian destruction, allowing intimate witness to register the spectacle's overwhelming presence

examples.quote: bitter, medicinal odor clung to me like stench
examples.scene: Narrator describes the overwhelming smell from the spice warehouse
examples.effect: Sensory detail creates atmosphere of corruption and contamination, suggesting how the changed world infiltrates and marks the individual

pedagogy_zone.heading: From Device Spotting to Analysis
pedagogy_zone.intro_text: Most students can identify a device. Strong analysis shows what it DOES. Don't just label it—explain its function in creating meaning.

content.question: Ask yourself: Why does the author use Imagery HERE? What meaning does it create in this specific moment?
content.framework: Use TVODE: Technique → Verb → Observation → Device effect → Evaluation

pedagogy_zone.essay_application: In your essays, always connect device to meaning. Show HOW the technique creates the effect, don't just identify that it's there.
